metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 552 of 1963 / Writ Petition No. 108 of 1960

facts.text: Property in dispute is agricultural land of about 60 acres at Nizamabad in former State of Hyderabad (now Andhra Pradesh).
On September 7, 1950, Deputy Custodian of Nizamabad allotted 44 acres of this land to five respondents (displaced persons) by way of lease.
By order dated July 21, 1951, balance 16 acres allotted to same five respondents. Lease stipulations: terms revised only after five years; no condition of personal cultivation imposed.

Government of India press note dated November 13, 1953 announced allotment of evacuee agricultural land in Hyderabad State to displaced persons with verified claims under Displaced Persons Claims Act, 1950, on quasi-permanent tenure terms as in Punjab.
Appellants made application pursuant to press note; on May 4, 1954, land allotted to appellants on quasi-permanent tenure despite subsisting lease to respondents.
Appellants satisfied qualifications for allotment under press note.
Revenue authorities, acting on allotment order, dispossessed respondents and put appellants in possession.
Respondents represented to Regional Settlement Commissioner, Bombay, that they were displaced persons rehabilitated by lease, had improved land.
Regional Settlement Commissioner order dated July 10, 1954 rejected respondents' application, one reason being failure to personally cultivate.
Respondents sought review from Regional Settlement Commissioner and intervention from Government of India.
Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 came into force on October 9, 1954.
Properties acquired by Government under s.12 by notification dated January 18, 1955.
Regional Settlement Commissioner issued sanads to appellants 1 to 4 under s.20 on January 12, 1956 without reference to respondents.
Deputy Chief Settlement Commissioner order dated August 22, 1958 set aside July 10, 1954 order, remanded for enquiry (passed without notice to appellants by inadvertence).
Collector enquiry report dated June 13, 1959 found respondents had personally cultivated the lands; noted 26 guntas allotted quasi-permanently to other displaced persons in 1954, out of controversy.
After remand, notice issued to appellants, heard them; Regional Settlement Commissioner referred case to Government of India under s.33 on November 3, 1959.

Deputy Secretary, Ministry of Rehabilitation order dated April 28, 1960: July 10, 1954 order wrong; no justification to terminate lease; revoke sanads to appellants, restore respondents to possession.

legal_issues.text: Whether Central Government had power under s.33 to revise Regional Settlement Commissioner order dated July 10, 1954 passed before Act came into force.
Whether sanads granted to appellants on January 12, 1956 could be revoked after quasi-permanent allotment, absent fraud or misrepresentation as per sanad terms.
Whether Deputy Secretary had materials to find July 10, 1954 order erroneous.

petitioner_arguments.text: Central Government had no power under s.33 to revise July 10, 1954 order as it was not a proceeding under the Act (pre-Act order).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 33, Section 39 of Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if revisable, land transferred irrevocably to appellants by quasi-permanent allotment and sanads; title under sanads in name of President could not be disturbed except per sanad terms (fraud/misrepresentation).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 20, Rule 91(8), Appendix XXIV; sanad clause on resumption

petitioner_arguments.text: Deputy Secretary had no materials to find July 10, 1954 order erroneous.

respondent_arguments.text: They were displaced persons entitled to allotment; incurred expenses improving land; unjustly dispossessed despite personal cultivation.

court_reasoning.text: S.33 empowers Central Government to call for any proceeding under Act and pass orders as circumstances require, not inconsistent with Act/rules. July 10, 1954 order deemed under Act by s.39 as action for rehabilitation grants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.39 validates pre-Act actions for compensation/rehabilitation as if under Act.

court_reasoning.text: Even if Central Govt should only set aside July 10 order, result same: restore respondents, dispossess appellants. Entire matter including original lease and restoration before Govt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rectifying error in rehabilitation grant to displaced persons.

court_reasoning.text: Sanad valid only on basis of valid allotment order. If allotment set aside, sanad and title fall with it. Follows Punjab HC in Balwant Kaur v. Chief Settlement Commissioner; dissents from Rajasthan HC in Partumal v. Managing Officer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No provision keeps grant alive after allotment order set aside.

court_reasoning.text: Materials existed: Collector found personal cultivation; no valid termination of lease.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deputy Secretary competent to find on materials.

holdings.text: Central Government has power under s.33 read with s.39 to revise pre-Act order relating to rehabilitation grant.
Sanad and title obtained thereunder do not survive if underlying allotment order is set aside.
Deputy Secretary had sufficient materials to set aside July 10, 1954 order.

precedents_cited.relevance: Rajasthan Full Bench held s.24 does not permit cancellation of completed sales; dissented from.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balwant Kaur v. Chief Settlement Commissioner
precedents_cited.relevance: Punjab Full Bench held title obtained on basis of allotment order falls if order set aside.

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Acquisition of property; sanads; revision powers; validation of pre-Act actions.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; writ petition under Art.32 also dismissed as it challenges same order.

key_quotes.text: "It is manifest that a sanad can be lawfully issued only on the basis of a valid order of allotment. If an order of allotment which is the basis upon which a grant is made is set aside it would follow... that the grant cannot survive."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on effect of setting aside allotment order on sanad.

key_quotes.text: "Section 39 enacts 'Anything done or any action taken (including any order made)... shall... be deemed to have been done or taken in the exercise of the powers conferred by or under this Act'."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Validates pre-Act order for revision under s.33.
